bioghist.p: Natalie Leota Henderson Hinderas (1927-1987) was a concert pianist and professor of music at Temple University. In 1945, Hinderas received her BS in Music from Oberlin Conservatory as their youngest student. She did her post-graduate work at the Julliard School of Music with Olga Samaroff and at the Philadelphia Conservatory with Edward Steuermann. In the 1950s and 1960s, Hinderas toured America, Europe, the West Indies, Africa, and Asia, and was signed by NBC to perform in recitals and variety shows at NBC-owned stations around the U.S. In 1966 she joined the faculty of Temple University's College of Music, where she rose to the rank of full professor. In 1971, she became the first Afican-American to perform a subscription concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra. She also performed with the Los Angeles Philharmonic orchestra, the Cleveland, Atlanta, New York, San Francisco, and Chicago symphony orchestras. Throughout her career, she promoted and recorded works by black performers and composers, among them R. Nathaniel Dett, William Grant Still, John W. Work, and George Walker. She received a number of awards and degrees including the Martha Baird Rockefeller fellowship and an honorary doctorate degree from Swarthmore College.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers and audio recordings of Natalie Hinderas. Materials include: programs for performances, appearances, and competitions; correspondence related to her performing and recording career; family correspondence; music scores; audio tapes of performances by Hinderas and others; audio tapes of interviews with others; reviews of her performances; articles, clippings, and promotional materials on other performers and composers; articles on topics related to music; financial records; photographs of Hinderas, her performances and tours, her husband Lionel Monagas, her daughter Michele Monagas, and other artists; notebooks and appointment books; a 1981 business diary related to Hinderas's work on "The Music Room" and selected performances; correspondence, notes and bibliographies related to "America Through Music"; a collection of postcards; and school records of Michele Monagas from kindergarten through high school.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
